questions.question: What is the SI unit of length?
questions.explanation: The meter is the fundamental SI unit of length, defined as the distance traveled by light in vacuum in 1/299,792,458 seconds.

questions.question: Which of the following is a vector quantity?
questions.explanation: Velocity is a vector quantity because it has both magnitude and direction, unlike speed which has only magnitude.

questions.question: A car accelerates uniformly from rest to 20 m/s in 5 seconds. What is its acceleration?
questions.explanation: Using v = u + at, where u=0, v=20 m/s, t=5 s: 20 = 0 + a×5 ⇒ a = 20/5 = 4 m/s²

questions.question: What is the weight of a 5kg mass on Earth? (g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation: Weight W = mg = 5 × 10 = 50 Newtons

questions.question: Which law states that every action has an equal and opposite reaction?
questions.explanation: Newton's third law of motion states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

questions.question: What is the momentum of a 2kg object moving at 3 m/s?
questions.explanation: Momentum p = mv = 2 × 3 = 6 kg m/s

questions.question: A force of 10N acts on a mass of 2kg. What is the acceleration?
questions.explanation: Using F = ma ⇒ 10 = 2a ⇒ a = 5 m/s²

questions.question: What is the work done when a 20N force moves an object 5m in the direction of the force?
questions.explanation: Work = Force × Distance = 20 × 5 = 100 Joules

questions.question: What is the kinetic energy of a 4kg mass moving at 3 m/s?
questions.explanation: KE = ½mv² = ½ × 4 × 3² = 2 × 9 = 18 J

questions.question: What is the power if 100J of work is done in 5 seconds?
questions.explanation: Power = Work/Time = 100/5 = 20 Watts

questions.question: Which simple machine has a mechanical advantage greater than 1?
questions.explanation: Both levers and single movable pulleys can have mechanical advantage greater than 1, while fixed pulleys have MA=1.

questions.question: What is the pressure exerted by a force of 100N on an area of 2m²?
questions.explanation: Pressure = Force/Area = 100/2 = 50 Pascals

questions.question: What is the density of a substance with mass 200g and volume 100cm³?
questions.explanation: Density = Mass/Volume = 200/100 = 2 g/cm³

questions.question: What is the relative density of a substance that floats on water?
questions.explanation: A substance floats on water if its relative density (compared to water) is less than 1.

questions.question: What is the upthrust on an object immersed in a fluid equal to?
questions.explanation: Archimedes' principle states that the upthrust on an object immersed in a fluid equals the weight of the fluid displaced.

questions.question: What is the principle behind the hydraulic press?
questions.explanation: Hydraulic press works on Pascal's principle which states that pressure applied to a confined fluid is transmitted equally in all directions.

questions.question: What is the temperature in Kelvin when it is 27°C?
Which method of heat transfer occurs in fluids?
questions.explanation: Convection is the method of heat transfer that occurs in fluids (liquids and gases) through the movement of the fluid itself.

questions.question: What is the specific heat capacity of a substance?
questions.explanation: Specific heat capacity is the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of 1kg of a substance by 1 Kelvin.

questions.question: What is the wavelength of a wave with frequency 50Hz and speed 340m/s?
questions.explanation: Using v = fλ ⇒ λ = v/f = 340/50 = 6.8 meters

questions.question: What type of wave requires a material medium for propagation?
questions.explanation: Mechanical waves require a material medium for propagation, unlike electromagnetic waves which can travel through vacuum.

questions.question: What is the frequency of a pendulum that makes 20 oscillations in 10 seconds?
questions.explanation: Frequency = Number of oscillations/Time = 20/10 = 2 Hz

questions.question: What is the period of a wave with frequency 0.5 Hz?
questions.explanation: Period T = 1/f = 1/0.5 = 2 seconds

questions.question: What is the speed of light in vacuum?
questions.explanation: The speed of light in vacuum is approximately 3 × 10⁸ meters per second.

questions.question: What is the law of reflection?

options.A: Angle of incidence equals angle of reflection

questions.explanation: The law of reflection states that the angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection, and both lie in the same plane.

questions.question: What is the refractive index of a medium?

options.A: Speed of light in vacuum/Speed of light in medium
options.B: Speed of light in medium/Speed of light in vacuum

questions.explanation: Refractive index n = c/v, where c is speed in vacuum and v is speed in medium.

questions.question: What is the critical angle?

options.A: Angle of incidence when angle of refraction is 90°

questions.explanation: Critical angle is the angle of incidence in the denser medium for which the angle of refraction in the rarer medium is 90°.

questions.question: What type of lens converges light rays?
questions.explanation: Convex lens (converging lens) brings parallel light rays together at a focal point.

questions.question: What is the power of a lens with focal length 0.5m?
questions.explanation: Power P = 1/f = 1/0.5 = 2 Diopters

questions.question: What is the SI unit of electric charge?
questions.explanation: The coulomb is the SI unit of electric charge.

questions.question: What is the current if 10 coulombs flow in 2 seconds?
questions.explanation: Current I = Q/t = 10/2 = 5 Amperes

questions.question: What is the voltage if 20J of energy is used to move 2C of charge?
questions.explanation: Voltage V = Energy/Charge = 20/2 = 10 Volts

questions.question: What is the resistance of a conductor if voltage is 12V and current is 3A?
questions.explanation: Using Ohm's law: R = V/I = 12/3 = 4 Ohms

questions.question: What is the equivalent resistance of two 6Ω resistors in parallel?
What is the power dissipated in a 10Ω resistor with 2A current?
questions.explanation: Power P = I²R = 2² × 10 = 4 × 10 = 40 Watts

questions.question: What is the force between two charges of 2C each separated by 1m in vacuum?
questions.explanation: Using Coulomb's law: F = kq₁q₂/r² = (9×10⁹ × 2 × 2)/1² = 3.6 × 10¹⁰ N

questions.question: What is the electric field intensity at a point?
questions.explanation: Electric field intensity E = F/q, force per unit positive charge.

questions.question: What is the potential difference between two points?
questions.explanation: Potential difference = Work done/Charge moved between the points.

questions.question: What is the capacitance of a capacitor that stores 10C at 5V?
questions.explanation: Capacitance C = Q/V = 10/5 = 2 Farads

questions.question: What is the energy stored in a 4F capacitor charged to 3V?
questions.explanation: Energy E = ½CV² = ½ × 4 × 3² = 2 × 9 = 18 Joules

questions.question: What is the magnetic field around a straight current-carrying conductor?
questions.explanation: The magnetic field around a straight current-carrying conductor forms concentric circles around the wire.

questions.question: What rule is used to find the direction of magnetic field around a current-carrying conductor?
questions.explanation: The right-hand grip rule: if you grip the wire with your right hand, thumb pointing in current direction, fingers show magnetic field direction.

questions.question: What is electromagnetic induction?

options.A: Production of EMF by changing magnetic field
options.B: Production of current by static charge

questions.explanation: Electromagnetic induction is the production of electromotive force (EMF) across a conductor when it is exposed to a changing magnetic field.

questions.question: What is Faraday's law?

options.A: Induced EMF proportional to rate of change of flux
options.B: Force on current in magnetic field

questions.explanation: Faraday's law states that the induced EMF in a circuit is proportional to the rate of change of magnetic flux through the circuit.

questions.question: What is Lenz's law?

options.A: Induced current opposes the change causing it

questions.explanation: Lenz's law states that the direction of induced current is such that it opposes the change causing it.

questions.question: What is the principle of transformer operation?
questions.explanation: Transformers work on the principle of electromagnetic induction - changing current in primary coil induces EMF in secondary coil.

questions.question: What is the turns ratio in a transformer if primary has 100 turns and secondary has 50 turns?
questions.explanation: Turns ratio = Np/Ns = 100/50 = 2:1

questions.question: What is the frequency of AC mains in Nigeria?
questions.explanation: The standard frequency for AC mains in Nigeria is 50 Hertz.

questions.question: What is the RMS value of AC current?
questions.explanation: RMS (Root Mean Square) value = Peak value/√2 for sinusoidal AC.

questions.question: What is the half-life of a radioactive substance?

options.A: Time for half atoms to decay
options.B: Time for all atoms to decay
options.C: Time for quarter atoms to decay

questions.explanation: Half-life is the time required for half of the radioactive atoms in a sample to decay.

questions.question: What is alpha radiation?
questions.explanation: Alpha radiation consists of helium nuclei (2 protons and 2 neutrons).

questions.question: What is beta radiation?
questions.explanation: Beta radiation consists of high-speed electrons emitted from the nucleus.

questions.question: What is gamma radiation?
questions.explanation: Gamma radiation is high-energy electromagnetic radiation emitted from the nucleus.

questions.question: What is the principle of conservation of energy?

options.A: Energy cannot be created or destroyed

questions.explanation: The principle of conservation of energy states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed from one form to another.

questions.question: What is the efficiency of a machine?
questions.explanation: Efficiency = (Useful output energy/Total input energy) × 100%

questions.question: What is the moment of a force?
questions.explanation: Moment of force = Force × Perpendicular distance from pivot

questions.question: What is the principle of moments?

options.A: Sum of clockwise moments = Sum of anticlockwise moments

questions.explanation: For a body in equilibrium, the sum of clockwise moments about a point equals the sum of anticlockwise moments about the same point.

questions.question: What is center of gravity?

options.A: Point where weight appears to act

questions.explanation: Center of gravity is the point through which the resultant weight of a body appears to act.

questions.question: What is stability of an object?

options.A: Ability to return to equilibrium when displaced

questions.explanation: Stability refers to an object's ability to return to its equilibrium position when slightly displaced.

questions.question: What is elasticity?

options.A: Property to regain original shape after deformation

questions.explanation: Elasticity is the property of a material to regain its original shape and size after the deforming force is removed.

questions.question: What is Hooke's law?
questions.explanation: Hooke's law states that the extension of an elastic material is directly proportional to the applied force, provided the elastic limit is not exceeded.

questions.question: What is the spring constant?
questions.explanation: Spring constant k = Force/Extension, measured in N/m.

questions.question: What is surface tension?
questions.explanation: Surface tension is the force acting per unit length perpendicular to an imaginary line drawn on the liquid surface.

questions.question: What is viscosity?
questions.explanation: Viscosity is the measure of a fluid's resistance to flow.

questions.question: What is Bernoulli's principle?
questions.explanation: Bernoulli's principle states that for an ideal fluid flowing steadily, the pressure decreases when the fluid speed increases.

questions.question: What is the equation of continuity?
questions.explanation: Equation of continuity: A₁v₁ = A₂v₂, where A is cross-sectional area and v is fluid speed.

questions.question: What is simple harmonic motion?

options.A: Motion where acceleration proportional to displacement

questions.explanation: Simple harmonic motion is motion where acceleration is directly proportional to displacement from equilibrium and directed towards equilibrium.

questions.question: What is the period of a simple pendulum?
questions.explanation: Period of simple pendulum T = 2π√(l/g), where l is length and g is gravity.

questions.question: What is the Doppler effect?

options.A: Change in frequency due to relative motion

questions.explanation: Doppler effect is the change in frequency or wavelength of a wave in relation to an observer moving relative to the wave source.

questions.question: What is resonance?
questions.explanation: Resonance occurs when a system is driven at its natural frequency, resulting in large amplitude oscillations.

questions.question: What is the photoelectric effect?
questions.explanation: Photoelectric effect is the emission of electrons from a metal surface when light of suitable frequency falls on it.

questions.question: What is Planck's constant?
questions.explanation: Planck's constant h = 6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ Joule-seconds.

questions.question: What is the work function?
questions.explanation: Work function is the minimum energy required to eject an electron from a metal surface.

questions.question: What is X-ray?
questions.explanation: X-rays are high frequency electromagnetic waves with wavelengths shorter than ultraviolet light.

questions.question: What is nuclear fission?
questions.explanation: Nuclear fission is the splitting of a heavy nucleus into lighter nuclei with release of energy.

questions.question: What is nuclear fusion?
questions.explanation: Nuclear fusion is the combining of light nuclei to form heavier nuclei with release of energy.

questions.question: What is the mass number?
questions.explanation: Mass number = Number of protons + Number of neutrons

questions.question: What is the atomic number?
questions.explanation: Atomic number = Number of protons in nucleus

questions.question: What are isotopes?

options.A: Same atomic number, different mass number
options.B: Same mass number, different atomic number

questions.explanation: Isotopes are atoms of the same element (same atomic number) with different mass numbers (different number of neutrons).

questions.question: What is a semiconductor?

options.A: Material with conductivity between conductor and insulator

questions.explanation: Semiconductors have electrical conductivity between that of conductors and insulators.

questions.question: What is a diode?

options.A: Device that allows current in one direction

questions.explanation: A diode is an electronic component that allows current to flow in one direction only.

questions.question: What is a transistor?
questions.explanation: A transistor is a semiconductor device used to amplify or switch electronic signals.

questions.question: What is the principle of superposition?

options.A: Net displacement is sum of individual displacements

questions.explanation: Principle of superposition: When two or more waves meet, the resultant displacement equals the vector sum of individual displacements.

questions.question: What is interference?

options.A: Superposition of waves from coherent sources

questions.explanation: Interference is the superposition of waves from coherent sources resulting in reinforcement or cancellation.

questions.question: What is diffraction?
questions.explanation: Diffraction is the spreading of waves around obstacles or through openings.

questions.question: What is polarization?

options.A: Restriction of vibration to one plane

questions.explanation: Polarization is the restriction of the vibration of transverse waves to one plane.

questions.question: What is a sound wave?
questions.explanation: Sound waves are longitudinal mechanical waves that require a medium for propagation.

questions.question: What is the speed of sound in air at 0°C?
questions.explanation: Speed of sound in air at 0°C is approximately 331 m/s.

questions.question: What is ultrasound?
questions.explanation: Ultrasound refers to sound waves with frequencies above 20,000 Hz, beyond human hearing range.

questions.question: What is the echo?
questions.explanation: Echo is the reflection of sound waves from a surface back to the listener.

questions.question: What is the principle of floatation?

options.A: Weight of floating body equals weight of fluid displaced
options.B: Volume of body equals volume displaced
options.C: Density of body equals density of fluid
options.D: Mass of body equals mass of fluid

questions.explanation: Principle of floatation: A floating body displaces its own weight of the fluid in which it floats.

questions.question: What is a manometer?
questions.explanation: A manometer is a device used to measure pressure using a column of liquid.

questions.question: What is a barometer?
questions.explanation: A barometer is an instrument used to measure atmospheric pressure.

questions.question: What is gauge pressure?
questions.explanation: Gauge pressure is the pressure measured relative to atmospheric pressure.

questions.question: What is absolute pressure?
questions.explanation: Absolute pressure = Gauge pressure + Atmospheric pressure

questions.question: What is the first law of thermodynamics?
questions.explanation: First law of thermodynamics: ΔU = Q - W, where ΔU is change in internal energy, Q is heat added, W is work done by system.

questions.question: What is Boyle's law?
questions.explanation: Boyle's law: For a fixed mass of gas at constant temperature, pressure is inversely proportional to volume.

questions.question: What is Charles' law?
questions.explanation: Charles' law: For a fixed mass of gas at constant pressure, volume is directly proportional to absolute temperature.

questions.question: What is the pressure law?
questions.explanation: Pressure law: For a fixed mass of gas at constant volume, pressure is directly proportional to absolute temperature.

questions.question: What is the ideal gas equation?
questions.explanation: Ideal gas equation: PV = nRT, where P is pressure, V is volume, n is number of moles, R is gas constant, T is temperature.

questions.question: What is latent heat?

options.A: Heat for phase change at constant temperature

questions.explanation: Latent heat is the heat required to change the phase of a substance at constant temperature.

questions.question: What is latent heat of fusion?

options.A: Heat for solid to liquid change
options.B: Heat for liquid to gas change

questions.explanation: Latent heat of fusion is the heat required to change unit mass of solid to liquid at constant temperature.

questions.question: What is latent heat of vaporization?

options.A: Heat for liquid to gas change
options.B: Heat for solid to liquid change

questions.explanation: Latent heat of vaporization is the heat required to change unit mass of liquid to vapor at constant temperature.

questions.question: What is a convex mirror?
questions.explanation: Convex mirror is a diverging mirror that spreads out light rays.

questions.question: What is a concave mirror?
questions.explanation: Concave mirror is a converging mirror that brings parallel light rays to a focus.

questions.question: What is the focal length?

options.A: Distance from mirror/lens to focal point

questions.explanation: Focal length is the distance from the mirror or lens to its focal point.

questions.question: What is the mirror formula?
questions.explanation: Mirror formula: 1/f = 1/u + 1/v, where f is focal length, u is object distance, v is image distance.

questions.question: What is magnification?
questions.explanation: Magnification m = v/u = height of image/height of object

questions.question: What is total internal reflection?

options.A: Complete reflection at boundary when angle > critical angle

questions.explanation: Total internal reflection occurs when light traveling from denser to rarer medium is completely reflected back at the boundary when the angle of incidence exceeds the critical angle.

questions.question: What is a prism?

options.A: Transparent optical element with flat polished surfaces

questions.explanation: A prism is a transparent optical element with flat, polished surfaces that refract light.

questions.question: What is dispersion?

options.A: Separation of white light into colors

questions.explanation: Dispersion is the separation of white light into its constituent colors due to different refractive indices for different wavelengths.

questions.question: What is a rainbow?

options.A: Dispersion of sunlight by water droplets

questions.explanation: Rainbow is caused by dispersion, refraction, and reflection of sunlight in water droplets.

questions.question: What is a real image?

options.A: Image formed where light actually converges

questions.explanation: A real image is formed where light rays actually converge and can be projected on a screen.

questions.question: What is a virtual image?

options.A: Image formed where light appears to come from

questions.explanation: A virtual image is formed where light rays appear to diverge from and cannot be projected on a screen.

questions.question: What is the lens formula?
questions.explanation: Lens formula: 1/f = 1/u + 1/v, where f is focal length, u is object distance, v is image distance.

questions.question: What is the power of accommodation?

options.A: Eye's ability to focus at different distances

questions.explanation: Power of accommodation is the ability of the eye to focus on objects at different distances by changing the focal length of the eye lens.

questions.question: What is myopia?
questions.explanation: Myopia (short-sightedness) is a defect where distant objects appear blurred because the image forms in front of the retina.

questions.question: What is hypermetropia?
questions.explanation: Hypermetropia (long-sightedness) is a defect where near objects appear blurred because the image forms behind the retina.

questions.question: What is astigmatism?
questions.explanation: Astigmatism is caused by irregular curvature of the cornea or lens, resulting in distorted vision.

questions.question: What is presbyopia?
questions.explanation: Presbyopia is age-related long-sightedness caused by loss of elasticity of the eye lens.

questions.question: What is a microscope?
questions.explanation: A microscope is an optical instrument used for viewing very small objects.

questions.question: What is a telescope?
questions.explanation: A telescope is an optical instrument used for viewing distant objects.

questions.question: What is the principle of conservation of linear momentum?

options.A: Total momentum before collision equals total after

questions.explanation: Principle of conservation of linear momentum: In the absence of external forces, the total momentum of a system remains constant.

questions.question: What is elastic collision?

options.A: Both momentum and kinetic energy conserved

questions.explanation: In elastic collision, both momentum and kinetic energy are conserved.

questions.question: What is inelastic collision?

options.A: Momentum conserved, kinetic energy not conserved

questions.explanation: In inelastic collision, momentum is conserved but kinetic energy is not conserved.

questions.question: What is projectile motion?

options.A: Motion under gravity with horizontal velocity

questions.explanation: Projectile motion is the motion of an object thrown into the air, subject to gravity, with constant horizontal velocity.

questions.question: What is the range of a projectile?
questions.explanation: Range is the horizontal distance traveled by a projectile before hitting the ground.

questions.question: What is the time of flight of a projectile?
questions.explanation: Time of flight is the total time a projectile remains in the air.
